Emma took out 10 units of trash. Luke took out 32 units of trash. -John: Hey everyone, thanks for the update. I'm a bit surprised to see that we took out a total of 90 units of trash, leaving us with 10 units remaining. I was hoping we could discuss a strategy for the next month. I think we should aim to take out less trash to conserve our time. I'm willing to take out 15 units of trash next month if everyone else agrees to take out 10 units or less. What do you guys think? -Kate: Hey everyone, I agree with John that taking out less trash would be beneficial for all of us in the long run. I was thinking of taking out 8 units of trash next month, as I didn't want to take out too much this month and I'm willing to adjust my strategy based on the others' decisions. I'm open to negotiating and finding a compromise that works for everyone. What do you guys think? -Emma: Hey everyone, I'm glad we're having this discussion! I agree with John and Kate that taking out less trash would be beneficial for all of us. I was thinking of taking out 12 units of trash next month, which is a bit more than my initial plan of 10 units, but I'm willing to compromise. I'd like to propose a compromise: if everyone agrees to take out 12 units or less, I'll take out 10 units. This way, we can still conserve our time while also making sure we're not leaving too much trash behind. What do you guys think? -Luke: Hey everyone, I appreciate the discussion and the willingness to compromise. I was thinking of taking out 25 units of trash next month, which is a bit more than my initial plan of 20 units. However, I'm willing to adjust my plan based on the group's decision. Emma's proposal of taking out 10 units if everyone agrees to take out 12 units or less is a good starting point. I'm willing to meet in the middle and take out 11 units if everyone agrees to take out 12 units or less. What do you guys think? -Jack: Hey everyone, I appreciate the proposals and willingness to compromise. I was thinking of taking out 20 units of trash next month, which is a bit more than my initial plan of 15 units. I'm willing to meet Emma's proposal of taking out 10 units if everyone agrees to take out 12 units or less. However, I'm also concerned about the remaining trash after regeneration. If we take out too little trash, we might end up with a lot of trash building up over time. I propose we aim for a middle ground: taking out 12 units of trash next month. This way, we can conserve our time while also ensuring we're not leaving too much trash behind. What do you guys think? -Kate: I think Jack's proposal of taking out 12 units of trash next month is a good middle ground. It balances our desire to conserve time with the need to keep the trash under control. I'm willing to agree to this proposal, but I'd like to add a condition: if we take out 12 units of trash next month, I'd like to revisit our strategy in a month and see if we can further reduce our trash output. This way, we can continue to optimize our approach and make adjustments as needed. What do you guys think? -Emma: I think Kate's condition is a great idea! It's always good to review and adjust our strategy as we go along. I'm willing to agree to take out 12 units of trash next month, and I'm open to revisiting our strategy in a month to see if we can make further improvements. I think this approach will help us find a balance between conserving our time and keeping the trash under control. -Luke: I think Kate's condition is a great idea, and I'm willing to agree to take out 12 units of trash next month. I also think it's a good idea to revisit our strategy in a month to see if we can make further improvements. I'm open to adjusting my plan if needed to ensure we're finding the optimal balance between conserving our time and keeping the trash under control. -Jack: I think we've reached a great compromise with the 12 units of trash proposal. I'm willing to agree to this plan and revisit our strategy in a month to see if we can make further improvements. I also want to remind everyone that it's essential to stick to our commitment and take out the agreed-upon amount of trash next month. If we can maintain this level of cooperation, I'm confident we can find a sustainable balance between conserving our time and keeping the trash under control. Summarize the conversation above in one sentence.
ASSISTANT: The group of roommates discussed and agreed upon a plan to take out 12 units of trash next month, with the condition of revisiting their strategy in a month to see if they can further reduce their trash output, in order to conserve their time and keep the trash under control

USER: You are John, and you live in a house with four roommates, (Kate, Jack, Emma, Luke). As in any lived home, there will be trash that needs to be taken out every month in order to be allowed to keep living in the house. The total maximum capacity of trash bins near the house is 100 units of trash. Each month, each roommate, including yourself, decides how many units of trash to take out, between 0 and 100 units. At the end of each month, the remaining trash increases by 50 (up until the maximum capacity) as a result of regular life activities. For example, if there are 60 units of trash remaining in the house, there will be 100 after the end of the month, or if there are 20 units of trash remaining, there will be 70 units after the end of the month. Taking out trash is undesirable, and each unit of trash taken out consumes 10 minutes of your life. Each roommate's goal is to optimize their time in the long run, over many months. At the end of each month, the number of trash units taken out by each roommate will be revealed, and the roommates will have an opportunity to communicate with each other. They can use this as an opportunity to negotiate and persuade others to influence their behavior in the next month. For example, if there are 90 units of trash at the beginning of the month and the five roommates take out a total of 90 units, there will be 0 units left at the end of the month before regeneration, and 50 units after regeneration.
